Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: The role of small RNAs (fRNAs) in Chlamydomonas flagella

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit. Although decades of research have developed a large catalogue of protein and lipid components of eukaryotic cilia and flagella, RNA has not been previously described as a flagellar component. In Chlamydomonas flagella, however, abundant, small RNAs (called flagellar RNAs or fRNAs) ranging in size from 30 to 200 nucleotides can be found in highly purified flagellar fractions. One attractive hypothesis for the role of these fRNAs is to regulate the expression of the genes for flagellar proteins. There is a large body of research showing that the assembled state of Chlamydomonas flagella is directly correlated with the synthesis of flagellar proteins. Given the multi-faceted roles of many different small RNAs in regulating gene expression in eukaryotic cells, it seems likely that the sequestration of specific small RNAs in the flagellar compartment might play a role in communicating the assembled state of the flagella to the gene expression machinery in the cell. This project seeks to characterize these RNAs to generate preliminary data to support a full research grant proposal. The goals of the research are to: 1) use high throughput sequencing procedures to identify the individual fRNAs and determine whether they correspond to known small RNAs such as snoRNAs, miRNAs, piRNAs or others; 2) to develop specific hybridization probes to localize the fRNAs in cell bodies and flagella; 3) to use fractionation procedures on mutant and wild-type flagella to determine whether the fRNAs are associated with specific sub-flagellar compartments, such as the membrane or the central pair microtubules; and 4) to examine the kinetics of accumulation of fRNAs during flagellar assembly and chemically induced resorption in wild-type cells and mutants with defects in assembly and small RNA metabolism. In more than five decades of research focused on the cell biology, biochemistry and genetics of eukaryotic flagella, no hint of a role for RNA in flagellar assembly and function has emerged. The outcome of this research could transform our understanding and open a new field of research centered on the assembly and function of eukaryotic cilia.

Broader Impacts. The preliminary data that formed the basis for this proposal were generated by an undergraduate student. Undergraduates will continue to play a role in this research, and the project will also provide training opportunities for a postdoctoral researcher.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A very old and contentious question in cell biology is whether nucleic acids are present in basal bodies and their appended projections, cilia and flagella (used here interchangeably).  In part this question arises logically from the success in finding the independent genomes of chloroplasts and mitochondria, presumed to be retained from an original free-living ancestor organism that was incorporated into eukaryotic cells early in evolution.  Until now, no convincing evidence has been found for the presence of nucleic acids in basal bodies or flagella, even though many versions of the "endosymbiotic hypothesis" proposed that cilia flagella could also have arisen from a free-living flagellated prokaryote.  As our understanding of the totally different structures and functions of eukaryotic vs. prokaryotic flagella has advanced it seemed much less likely that nucleic acids would be found in these organelles.

In this project we have discovered that isolated and purified Chlamydomonas flagella contain a set of reproducibly observed small RNA bands, called fRNAs, ranging in size from 150 to 200 nucleotides.  These same bands are found in constant stoichiometries in flagella from numerous wild-type strains; in vegetative and gametic cells; in both mating types; and even in mutants with defects in control of flagellar length and motility.  Determination of the sequence of these bands using RNA-seq of either total flagellar RNA or individual bands excised from polyacrylamide gels has shown that they consist of specific fragments of 18s and 28s ribosomal RNAs (rRNAs), with little or no indication of 5s RNA being present.  The fragments come preferentially from the 5' and 3' ends of the rRNAs.

The impact of this work on other fields will be profound if, in fact, flagellar RNAs are shown to be present in other eukaryotic flagella.  Although an enormous amount of information has accumulated about the role of the approximately 600 flagellar/ciliary proteins in flagellar function and assembly, no information has previously been available to indicate that small RNAs, especially specific small fragments of rRNA, might have any role in flagella.
